title: Are oxygen and air the same? - Quora

response.answer_text: Formally, they are different things. “Air” has O2 (oxygen) as one of the components of the mixture that is “air”. However we breathe in 21% O2 in air, and breathe out about 16% O2 (and increase CO2). So in a confined space, “air” is all about the percent of oxygen, and whether not we can thrive in whatever percentage of oxygen is present. Most buildings are not hermetically sealed, some significant air exchange occurs, which carries in more O2 and carries out some CO2.

No. Air is a mixture consisting most of nitrogen, oxygen and a variable amount of water vapour, along with some carbon dioxide and a number of trace elements. Oxygen is a pure substance, referring either to the atom or the diatomic gas, the latter being a part of the air. Nevertheless, air is sometimes used to refer to oxygen.

Oxygen is a part of the air. Air contains nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, argon, water vapour etc. Nitrogen is the largest component (78%) followed by Oxygen (21%) approx. Oxygen is a pure substance. Air is a mixture. Hopefully the difference is now clear.
No. Oxygen is a gas containing O2 molecules. Air is a mixture of several gasses composed of primarily nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, water vapor, and other trace gasses.
No. Oxygen is a single type of gas, and air is Earth’s atmosphere, which composes of nitrogen, oxygen, methane, carbon dioxide, etc.
No because air is in the atmosphere and oxygen is pass out by trees so they are not same
